Why Postgres - http://www.craigkerstiens.com/2017/04/30/why-postgres-five-years-later/


Postgres (post-gress-Q-L)
  • an open source relational database management system (DBMS) 
  • 2 important datatypes
    • JSONB - binary representation of JSON
      • capable of being indexed on with GIN and GIST index types
      • can query into your full JSON document for quick lookups
    • Range types - with a single column you have a range from one value to another
      • especially helpful for time ranges
      • can have certain contraints that certain time stamps can’t overlap or other contraints
    • Extensions - key to community and growth of Postgres
      • allow you to hook into Postgres very natively without requiring them to be committed back to the core of Postgres
      • you can add rich functionality without being tied to a Postgres release and review cycles
      • examples: 
        • Citrus - turns Postgres into a distributed database allowing you to easily shard your database across multiple nodes; app looks like single db, then under covers it’s spread across multiple physical machines and Postgres instances
        • HyperLogLog - allows to easily have close-enough distinct counts pre-aggregated, but also do various operations on them across days (unions, intersections, etc)
        • PostGIS - considered most advanced geospactial db; adds new advanced geospatial db, operators and makes it easy to do many location based activities for dealing with mapping and routing
    • Biggest knock against Postgres: difficulty in setting up replication, like streaming replication 
      • tools like wal-e help leverage much of Postgres mechanisms of things like disaster recovery
      • Logical replication - allows spending of more or less actual commands - you can replicate only certain commands or certain tables
  • Scale 
    • usability features of Postgres continue to get better at performance
      • foundations for parallelism and on some queries 
  • Richer indexing
    • already have powerful indexing before GIN and GiST (useful for JSONB)
    • KNN indexes and Sp-GiST 
  • Upset
  • Foreign Data Wrappers
    • you can map an external data system to tables directly in Postgres 
      • example: query your Redis db from directly in Postgres with SQL
